author: By Harvey Araton
title: The Root of the Knicks’ Success? Caring When They Didn’t Have To.
description: In a season of uncertainty, the Knicks gave fans, and opponents, one thing to count on: “They were coming to play,” one observer said.
content: Of all the postseason-ensuring victories across the Knicks’ grand reawakening of a regular season, none rose to the level of their most compelling, collective triumph. That would be the defeat of every team’s most formidable opponent: the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch and Austin Ramzy
title: Vaccinations are rising in the European Union after a long, slow start.
description: The increase underscores the global disparities in vaccination efforts.
content: Vaccinations are picking up pace in the European Union, a stunning turnaround after the bloc’s immunization drive stalled for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Start off with a baked rajma, move into tofu, and finish off the week with pork tenderloin.
content: Good morning. Happy Mother’s Day to all those women who’ve shouldered so much parental work during these last 14 months, and happy Mother’s Day personally to Dorie Greenspan, who brought us an incredible new recipe for gâteau Basque (above) this week. We all ought to make it today in honor of maternity, or Basque culture, or just because it’s delicious: two disks of rolled-out airy-crumbly dough with a baked-in filling of pastry cream or jam. It’s a cake that resembles a cake, Dorie writes in her column, as much as Boston cream pie resembles a pie — which is to say not at all. Eat it with your fingers for dessert tonight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawna Richer
title: Connor McDavid Hits 100 Points in 53 Games. He’s Not Done Yet.
description: The Oilers star had four points against the Canucks to reach one of the N.H.L.’s most meaningful milestones, but he is focused most on the playoffs.
content: A week in hockey that began and unfolded beneath a dark shadow cast by fisticuffs and fines ended with the game’s truest marker of a great season, from its most exciting player.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah M. Broom
title: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie: ‘My Madness Will Now Bare Itself’
description: In “Notes on Grief,” the author mourns the father she lost suddenly in June 2020.
content: NOTES ON GRIEF By Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Yankees Get a Walk-Off Win With a 50-Foot Single
description: A win over Washington put the Yankees over .500. For the Mets, Lindor and McNeil got back to baseball, leading the team to a win.
content: The smallest of hits decided a huge pitching matchup.
source.name: The New York Times

title: From The Sunday Read Archive: ‘The Accusation’
description: One writer undertook an examination of the truth, at a moment when facts seemed malleable.
content: In this episode of The Sunday Read, we revisit a story from our archives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: A Boxer May Miss the Olympics Because of Her Prepandemic Pregnancy
description: Olympic organizers changed how boxers from the Americas would qualify for Tokyo because of the pandemic. Now one of the best Canadians is on the outside looking in.
content: The Tokyo Olympics were supposed to be Mandy Bujold’s swan song, a capstone to the career of one of Canada’s best amateur boxers. Bujold, a 33-year old flyweight, has won 11 Canadian national championships, two Pan American Games titles, and a trip to the Rio de Janeiro Games in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: The Psychedelic Revolution Is Coming. Psychiatry May Never Be the Same.
description: Psilocybin and MDMA are poised to be the hottest new therapeutics since Prozac. Universities want in, and so does Wall Street. Some worry a push to loosen access could bring unintended consequences.
content: It’s been a long, strange trip in the four decades since Rick Doblin, a pioneering psychedelics researcher, dropped his first hit of acid in college and decided to dedicate his life to the healing powers of mind-altering compounds. Even as antidrug campaigns led to the criminalization of Ecstasy, LSD and magic mushrooms, and drove most researchers from the field, Dr. Doblin continued his quixotic crusade with financial help from his parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukraine’s Burial Mounds Offer Meaning in a Heap of History
description: The Scythians, marijuana-smoking nomadic warriors of ancient Ukraine, built thousands of burial mounds that are at risk today. A preservation group finds resonance in them for a country at war.
content: DNIPRO, Ukraine — Belching diesel exhaust, a bulldozer cut into a 4,000-year-old burial mound, peeling back the soil to reveal the mysteries hidden inside, including a skeleton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Maya Angelou and Sally Ride Will Be Honored on Quarters
description: The coins are part of a new U.S. Mint program that will feature as many as 20 American women.
content: The writer and poet Maya Angelou and the astronaut Sally Ride, the first American woman to fly in space, are the first women who will appear on a series of quarters to be issued by the U.S. Mint over the next four years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | May 10, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Where Are the Jobs?
description: The new jobs report was surprisingly bad.
content: Good morning and happy Mother’s Day. (Hi, mom!) Here’s the news you need to know for the week ahead in business and tech. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Marcus Payadue
title: Voting Rights, Afghanistan, Mother’s Day: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer and Aaron Krolik
title: Online Cheating Charges Upend Dartmouth Medical School
description: The university accused 17 students of cheating on remote exams, raising questions about data mining and sowing mistrust on campus.
content: HANOVER, N.H. — Sirey Zhang, a first-year student at Dartmouth’s Geisel School of Medicine, was on spring break in March when he received an email from administrators accusing him of cheating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Elon Musk Hosts a Mother’s Day Episode of ‘Saturday Night Live’
description: The much-discussed Tesla and SpaceX executive took a self-deprecating approach, telling viewers, “I’m pretty good at running human in emulation mode.”
content: In the end, an episode of “Saturday Night Live” hosted by Elon Musk turned out to be exactly that, no more and no less.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Pete du Pont, Ex-Delaware Governor Who Ran for President, Dies at 86
description: Bored with working at his family’s chemical company, Mr. du Pont entered politics and led an economic turnaround of his debt-ridden home state.
content: Pete du Pont, the scion of one of America’s wealthiest families and a two-term Republican governor of Delaware who presided over an economic revival in his debt-ridden state and in 1988 ran for the presidency, died on Saturday at his home in Wilmington, Del. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: ‘No Doubt in My Mind’: Scott Stringer’s Accuser Details Harassment Claims
description: Jean Kim said in an interview that Mr. Stringer, a Democratic candidate for mayor, had abused a position of power to make unwanted advances. He has denied her allegations.
content: He was an ambitious state assemblyman and a rising star in the liberal hothouse of Upper West Side politics. She was a New York newcomer, born in South Korea, raised in Ohio and eager to break into the city’s thriving Democratic scene.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Trump Keeps an Iron Grip on the G.O.P.
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 9, 2021.
content: “Republicans need to go back to kitchen-table issues that voters really care about, sprinkle in a little culture here and there but not get carried away. And some of them are making an industry out of getting carried away.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mimi Swartz
title: Could Matthew McConaughey Be All Right, All Right, All Right for Texas?
description: Maybe Texas needs a philosopher-king to lead it.
content: HOUSTON — When I first heard the rumors that Matthew McConaughey was considering a run for governor of Texas, my reaction was fury. Did he not recall Kinky Friedman, the musician-comedian-novelist-gadfly whose candidacy in 2006 helped blow up the Democratic vote and gave us Rick Perry as governor for 14 years?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: In Arizona, a Troubled Voting Review Plods On as Questions Mount
description: A makeshift review of the vote in the state’s largest county has pleased followers of former President Donald J. Trump but is being widely criticized as a partisan exercise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and David E. Sanger
title: U.S. and Iran Want to Restore the Nuclear Deal. They Disagree Deeply on What That Means.
description: After five weeks of diplomatic shadow boxing, it is clear that the old agreement no longer works for Tehran or Washington, except as a steppingstone.
content: President Biden and Iran’s leaders say they share a common goal: They both want to re-enter the nuclear deal that President Donald J. Trump scrapped three years ago, restoring the bargain that Iran would keep sharp limits on its production of nuclear fuel in return for a lifting of sanctions that have choked its economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: A ‘Party in the Bardo’ for a City in Transition
description: At the Park Avenue Armory, Laurie Anderson and Jason Moran gathered fellow artists to conjure a sonic environment haunted by the pandemic.
content: New York City is in a liminal state: partially vaccinated while still in the grip of Covid-19; beckoning cautiously masked people outside with the blossoming spring; and reopening indoor performance venues at last, but with caveats that color every show with reminders of the continuing pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: The Philharmonic Grows in a Shipping Container in Brooklyn
description: With a focus on community partnerships, the orchestra’s Bandwagon 2 is traveling around New York City this month.
content: There are no seats at the moment in David Geffen Hall, the New York Philharmonic’s home at Lincoln Center. There is no lobby, no stage, no stairs. The theater — currently in the midst of a long-delayed renovation — is a raw shell of concrete and steel; the only music within it, the shouts of workers and the deafening screech of metal being sawed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Mary Stuart’ Review: A Battle Royal in a Brooklyn Apartment
description: With four actors and a contemporary setting, Bedlam offers an audacious, if half-baked, take on the Schiller play about the fate of Mary, Queen of Scots.
content: Two queens, a gaggle of self-serving politicians, a murder plot, a rivalry for regal dominance: George R.R. Martin has nothing on the annals of English history. That’s why the stories appeal to so many, from the writer and historian Philippa Gregory to the 18th-century German poet-playwright Friedrich Schiller, whose verse play “Mary Stuart,” about the imprisonment and final days of the famous Queen of Scots, has proved a steady stage draw, especially for zealous actresses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: A potentially fatal fungal infection is cropping up among India’s Covid patients.
description: The condition, known as mucormycosis, seems to be infecting some Covid patients with weakened immune systems and underlying conditions, particularly diabetes.
content: NEW DELHI — Doctors in India are concerned about an increasing number of potentially fatal fungal infections affecting either people who have Covid-19 or those who have recently recovered from the disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: Schools Are Open, but Many Families Remain Hesitant to Return
description: Even as fears of the coronavirus abate, many students are continuing to opt out of in-person learning. Some school leaders are trying to woo — or push — them back.
content: Pauline Rojas’s high school in San Antonio is open. But like many of her classmates, she has not returned, and has little interest in doing so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Scott and Andy and All the Boys’ Review: Ripped From the Headlines
description: Mike Daisey takes sluggish aim at juicy targets: the disgraced Broadway producer Scott Rudin and the New York governor, Andrew M. Cuomo.
content: A lot of us have gotten rusty at talking face to face — at stringing our thoughts together in a coherent and entertaining way. Desperate to commune as we slowly emerge from our pandemic hibernation, we’re a little woozy still from all the isolation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Whet Moser
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A vaccine crisis in India.
content: The Serum Institute, the world’s largest vaccine maker, had vowed to take a leading role in India’s fight against Covid-19, and the country’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, had pledged its vaccines would “save humanity.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clare Walker Leslie
title: To Draw Nature, Pick Up a Pencil and Really Look
description: With a few basic tips you can begin to draw the creatures around you, and remember the joy they bring.
content: If you enjoy watching birds floating by or chipmunks scampering across your lawn, why not have a go at drawing them to remember what gave you some cheer? With a few basic tips, you can begin making simple drawings. Don’t worry about how good they are. Enjoy that you are learning to see nature. As the writer and naturalist Rachel Carson said, “Those who notice nature will never be bored.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Cirque du Soleil’s Return Could Be Its Most Challenging Feat Yet
description: After shuttering dozens of shows and shedding most of its work force, the vaunted Canadian circus faces an uphill struggle to bounce back.
content: MONTREAL — Confinement has posed a particular challenge for the Québécois aerialist Guillaume Paquin. Practicing signature moves, like twisting his way up a 20-foot rope before spinning downward like a helicopter propeller, is a bit tricky from his cramped living room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: When Covid Hit, China Was Ready to Tell Its Version of the Story
description: The government has been using its money and power to create an alternative to a global news media dominated by outlets like the BBC and CNN.
content: In the fall of 2019, just before global borders closed, an international journalists’ association decided to canvass its members about a subject that kept coming up in informal conversations: What is China doing?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Ed Ward, Rock Critic and Historian, Is Dead at 72
description: His reviews for Crawdaddy, Rolling Stone and Creem were admired. But his tough criticism at The Austin American-Statesman inspired a “Dump Ed Ward” movement.
content: Ed Ward, an uncompromising rock ‘n’ roll critic for Rolling Stone, The Austin American-Statesman and other publications who was also the rock historian on NPR’s “Fresh Air” and the author of two acclaimed books about rock, was found dead on May 3 at his home in Austin, Texas. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: As Scrutiny of Cryptocurrency Grows, the Industry Turns to K Street
description: Companies behind digital currencies are rushing to hire well-connected lobbyists, lawyers and consultants as the battle over how to regulate them intensifies.
content: WASHINGTON — When federal regulators late last year accused one of the world’s most popular cryptocurrency platforms of illegally selling $1.38 billion worth of digital money to investors, it was a pivotal moment in efforts to crack down on a fast-growing market — and in the still-nascent industry’s willingness to dive deeply into the Washington influence game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: George Jung, Who Made Millions Smuggling Cocaine, Dies at 78
description: Part of the Medellín drug cartel, he was imprisoned multiple times and was later played by Johnny Depp in the 2001 movie “Blow.”
content: George Jung, a cocaine smuggler who, at the height of his criminal career in the 1970s and ’80s, reaped millions of dollars a day from running drugs through the notorious Medellín cartel, died on Wednesday in hospice care in his hometown, Weymouth, Mass. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Danya Issawi
title: Watch an Opera and Run a Race From Home
description: This week, check in with NASA’s Perseverance rover, listen to orchestral music or celebrate Eid al-Fitr by making a custard dessert.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Kentucky Derby Winner Medina Spirit Fails Drug Test
description: The Hall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert, whose horses have failed five tests in a little more than a year, was suspended, but he denied wrongdoing.
content: The 2021 Kentucky Derby winner, Medina Spirit, failed a drug test after the race, putting a new stain on a sport troubled by doping problems and placing thoroughbred horse racing’s most recognizable personality, the Hall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert, under uncomfortable scrutiny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Obamas Are Freed in Their Blackness
description: They can finally be just as angry and unsettled as the rest of us.
content: On Monday, “CBS This Morning” will air a longer interview between Gayle King and the former first lady Michelle Obama. In a portion already released, Ms. Obama discussed the statement that she and former President Barack Obama issued after Derek Chauvin was found guilty of murdering George Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Goodnough
title: Fauci says indoor mask guidance should ‘start being more liberal’ as more Americans get vaccinated.
description: The comments from President Biden’s chief medical adviser came just two days after the C.D.C. belatedly highlighted the danger of airborne transmission.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci said on Sunday that he was open to relaxing indoor masking rules as more Americans get vaccinated against the virus, just two days after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention belatedly emphasized the danger of airborne transmission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Village Caught in Czech-Russia Spy Case Just Wants Things to Stop Blowing Up
description: Was a huge blast at a Czech weapons depot sabotage by Russian spies? The villagers where it happened aren’t sure, but they do know they only want to watch James Bond films, not live inside one.
content: VLACHOVICE-VRBETICE, Czech Republic — For nearly a century, local residents have wondered at the strange comings and goings at a sealed-off camp ringed by barbed wire and dotted with keep out signs on the edge of their village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Turkey’s second major wave has begun to recede, though its lockdown is far from tight.
description: The government ordered nonessential workers to stay home starting on April 29, but many of the country’s workers are exempt.
content: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s health ministry on Saturday reported fewer than 20,000 new coronavirus cases in the previous 24 hours, a first since mid-March and 10 days into a lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: One of the N.F.L.’s Fastest Is Among the Slowest on the Track
description: DK Metcalf, the All-Pro Seattle receiver, finished last in his heat on Sunday in his first 100-meter race against professional sprinters.
content: WALNUT, Calif. — DK Metcalf launched slowly from the starting blocks, faded over 100 meters and learned in 10.363 seconds on Sunday that elite football speed does not translate easily to elite track speed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Chris Cameron
title: McCarthy Officially Backs Stefanik to Replace Cheney in House Leadership
description: “We need to be united,” said the Republican leader Kevin McCarthy, who worked behind the scenes for days on behalf of Representative Elise Stefanik of New York.
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Kevin McCarthy, the minority leader, on Sunday officially endorsed Representative Elise Stefanik in her bid to oust the No. 3 House Republican, Representative Liz Cheney, who has hemorrhaged support over her repudiation of former President Donald J. Trump’s lies about election fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Canelo Álvarez Has Three Belts and All the Numbers in His Corner
description: The supermiddleweight champion pounded Billy Joe Saunders in front of 73,126 spectators in Texas and wants the I.B.F. champion Caleb Plant next.
content: The 73,126 paid spectators who watched the supermiddleweight champion Saul Álvarez pound Billy Joe Saunders into submission over eight rounds on Saturday night at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, set an attendance record at an indoor boxing match in the United States. Their presence proved that boxing, a sport often declared dead, or at least passé, can still draw a robust audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: ‘Why Do We Deserve to Die?’ Kabul’s Hazaras Bury Their Daughters.
description: A bomb attack that killed scores of schoolgirls, members of a long-persecuted minority, offered still more evidence that Afghanistan may be on the verge of unraveling.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — One by one they brought the girls up the steep hill, shrouded bodies covered in a ceremonial prayer cloth, the pallbearers staring into the distance. Shouted prayers for the dead broke the silence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Mark Abramson
title: ‘Will I Recognize You?’ She Traveled 2,500 Miles to Reach Her Mother.
description: Migrant children are crossing the southwestern border by the thousands each week. They are often rejoining parents who immigrated to the United States years ago.
content: LOS ANGELES — Ana Paredes paced back and forth in anxious anticipation, her eyes on the escalator disgorging passengers into the baggage claim area. When the little girl emerged, Ms. Paredes rushed forward to clutch and caress her. But 10-year-old Melissa, the daughter she had not seen for seven years, at first embraced her only halfheartedly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israeli Court Delays Expulsion of Palestinian Families in East Jerusalem
description: The threat to evict six families from the East Jerusalem neighborhood of Sheikh Jarrah had become a rallying cry for Palestinians.
content: JERUSALEM — The Israeli Supreme Court delayed on Sunday a decision on whether to expel six Palestinian families from their homes in East Jerusalem after the attorney general requested more time, in part because of the tensions the case has stirred.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 9, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 9, 2021.
content: An article this weekend on Page 6 about a cohort of prizewinning theater directors who are questioning the norms of their industry misattributes a quote to one of the directors interviewed. Tyne Rafaeli said, “This has been an indescribably devastating time for our community, so I feel like we must say that very clearly. But I think, occasionally, with great hardship comes growth”; not Danya Taymor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norman Mayersohn
title: So Your Car Has Been Recalled. Now What?
description: Recalls are common, but receiving a notice can still be unnerving. Here’s what to expect.
content: Millions of cars are recalled each year, and roughly eight million already have been in 2021, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Getting a notice from the automaker that your vehicle is among them and has a safety deficiency is not only alarming, it can also lead to a flood of questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Apt Name for a Car Mechanic
description: Zhouqin Burnikel brightens our Monday.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — It’s possible that solvers who are new to crosswords don’t really notice themes, and if they don’t, I think they’re missing out. Themes add a bit of color to the more straightforward early week puzzles — where new solvers theoretically start to build experience before being subjected to the twisted clues of later week puzzles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Hacked Pipeline May Stay Shut for Days, Raising Concerns About Fuel Supply
description: While the impact has been limited so far, some energy analysts warned of possible shortages and higher prices as the suspension continues.
content: HOUSTON — The operator of the largest petroleum pipeline between Texas and New York, which was shut down after a ransomware attack, declined on Sunday to say when it would reopen, raising concerns about a critical piece of infrastructure that carries nearly half of the East Coast’s fuel supplies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Where Is Country Music Making Room for Women?
description: Nashville remains challenging for women artists. But some rising performers are breaking through on radio — and TikTok.
content: For the last several years, the obstacles female performers face in country music have been widely documented and discussed, yet conditions haven’t improved much. The genre favors a handful of big stars, and offers few opportunities for growth to younger ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: After a Traumatizing Year, Black People Turn to Therapy
description: The death of George Floyd and other high-profile police killings have prompted African-Americans to seek help, mental health experts say.
content: In the aftermath of the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis last year, mental health experts across the country say they have seen African-Americans, whose skepticism of therapy has been documented by research, seeking it in growing numbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elijah Megginson
title: When I Applied to College, I Didn’t Want to ‘Sell My Pain’
description: Yes, I’m a student from the “hood.” But we have more to offer than our adversity.
content: In school, most kids are told that they have the potential to do great things in life. They’re told the sky’s the limit. As I started to be recognized as a promising student, around eighth grade, I was told, “You’re smart and you’re from the hood, you’re from the projects, colleges will love you.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Older Man Was Standing by the Doors and Waiting to Exit the Train’
description: A dropped glove, a passenger striking a pose and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Peck
title: Policymakers Used to Ignore Child Care. Then Came the Pandemic.
description: Experts who sounded the alarm about the care economy were often shunted to the side of policy discussions. Not anymore.
content: When the economist Nancy Folbre got a call from the MacArthur Foundation in 1998, she was expecting rejection: a courtesy call to deny the funding application she’d submitted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: 7 Dead in Shooting at Birthday Party in Colorado, Police Say
description: The gunman shot and killed six adults before taking his own life at a mobile home park, officials said. A motive was not yet known.
content: DENVER — A shooting at a birthday party in Colorado Springs early on Sunday morning left six people and the gunman dead, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: After Times Square Shooting, Adams and Yang Stress Support for N.Y.P.D.
description: Eric Adams and Andrew Yang, among the front-runners in the New York City mayor’s race, said the shooting underlined the importance of public safety.
content: Within hours of a shooting in Times Square that left three bystanders, including a child, wounded, two news conferences were held near the crime scene: one by the Police Department, one by an elected official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: 2 Oklahoma Boys Pulled From Class for ‘Black Lives Matter’ T-Shirts
description: In addition to the disciplinary action they have faced, the boys’ mother said that at least one of her three sons has been bullied because of the shirts.
content: Two brothers, 8 and 5, were removed from their Oklahoma elementary school classrooms this past week and made to wait out the school day in a front office for wearing T-shirts that read “Black Lives Matter,” according to the boys’ mother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Champions League Final Considers a Move to London
description: UEFA officials and the British government will discuss shifting the Manchester City-Chelsea game from Istanbul to Wembley to sidestep coronavirus travel restrictions.
content: European soccer’s governing body will hold talks with the British government on Monday about moving this month’s Champions League final to London because travel restrictions related to the coronavirus pandemic have made it almost impossible for domestic fans of the finalists — the Premier League rivals Manchester City and Chelsea — to attend the match at its scheduled site in Istanbul.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Going Big: How Joe Biden Is Like F.D.R.
description: How Presidents Biden and Franklin D. Roosevelt both seized moments of crisis to do big things. Also: Park Avenue in bloom.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Examining the Use of the N-Word
description: Readers discuss a Sunday Review essay that spells out the slur and whether its use is acceptable in any context.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
